audience: High school students preparing for the SAT (Reading & Writing)

teacher_notes.materials: Printed mini-graphs, projector, and ruler if needed.
teacher_notes.assessment: 4-item unit check and one-sentence trend paraphrase.

learning_objectives: Read titles, axes, and units before interpreting.
Match claims precisely to data points or trends.

structure.title: Command of Evidence (Quantitative)
objectives: Translate numeric changes into plain language.

lecture_script.script: Start with title, variables, and units. Read exact values and compare the right numbers for the claim.
Annotate a small table and select the statement that mirrors the data-no more, no less.
If the claim says ‘largest increase,’ which two values must you compare? Answer succinctly.

worked_example.passage: Table: Year1=40, Year2=50, Year3=70 participants in a science fair.
worked_example.question: Which statement is best supported?

options.B: Largest increase was from Year2 to Year3.

worked_example.explanation: Increases are +10 and +20; the larger is 2→3.

practice_set.passage: Bar chart: Jan 200, Feb 220, Mar 260 library visits.
practice_set.question: Which choice describes the trend?

unit_check.question: First step with figures is to read

homework: Summarize trends for three mini-graphs in one sentence each.
Write one accurate and one inaccurate claim for a table; explain why.
Complete four quantitative evidence items and note compared values.
